Summary: The field of multiple sclerosis (MS) research continues to grow, with potential breakthroughs in treatments for progression and remyelination expected in the next few years. MS is a mysterious autoimmune disease that causes inflammation and neurodegeneration in the central nervous system. Recent research has shown that chronic cerebrospinal venous insufficiency (CCSVI) is a major contributor to MS, and that treating this condition can lead to improvements in symptoms and disease progression. Stem cell therapy is also being explored as a potential treatment for MS, with the goal of repairing the neurological damage caused by the disease. The vagus nerve is also being studied as a potential target for MS treatment, with microglial mirna being a focus of research. The latest research in MS is being presented at the ECTRIMS meeting in Milan, with a focus on spinal cord lesions, volume, and the spinal cord reserve.

Summary: Breastfeeding recommendations in women with multiple sclerosis (MS) should encourage exclusive breastfeeding. Family planning in women of childbearing age with MS should be included in standard clinical care, especially to choose the right treatment plans based on pregnancy desire. MS treatment should not be compromised because there are solutions. In Milan, 78.8% of women discussed pregnancy in advance with at least one member of their MS team. 68.6% of pregnant women were exposed to disease-modifying therapies (DMT) or had received previous induction therapies; 41.6% were still on DMT at the start of the second trimester. The most common DMT during pregnancy was natalizumab and glatiramer acetate. Another important abstract using data from Milan found that many women will not have completed their family by the time of diagnosis, and MS nurses share their experience on how important it is to have an in-depth understanding of the concerns that women have about pregnancy and breastfeeding in MS.

Summary: Satralizumab, a monoclonal antibody targeting interleukin-5 (IL-5), has demonstrated long-term efficacy in patients with autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 1 (APS1) and autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 2 (APS2), according to a recent study presented at the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology (AAAAI) annual meeting. The study, which included 11 patients with APS1 and 10 patients with APS2, found that satralizumab significantly reduced the frequency and severity of exacerbations in both groups. Additionally, the study found that satralizumab was well-tolerated and had a favorable safety profile. These findings suggest that satralizumab may be a promising treatment option for patients with APS1 and APS2.

Summary: This recent study presented at the MS Milan conference focused on the use of autologous mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) in patients with progressive multiple sclerosis (PMS). The study showed significant cognitive and biomarker improvements among patients who received repeated intrathecal injections of autologous MSCs compared to those who did not. The study also highlighted the importance of monitoring lymphopenia in patients receiving MSC therapy, as grade 4 lymphopenia can occur and may not be predictable. The study was well-received at the conference, with many researchers expressing interest in the use of MSCs in MS treatment.

Summary: The optimal dosage for subcutaneous ocrelizumab was uncovered in findings from the phase 1b ocarina i trial and was also presented at the recent MS Milan. The noninferiority of subcutaneous ocrelizumab compared with IV in relapsing and primary progressive MS was demonstrated in interim results from the chimes trial presented at MS Milan. The safety and efficacy of ocrevus in treating relapsing multiple sclerosis in black and Hispanic patients were also shown in the chimes trial. The latest findings shed light on the critical connection between b-cell levels and ocrelizumab's effectiveness in neurology. Most MS patients treated with a new under-the-skin formulation of ocrevus had no relapses or new MRI activity over six months, data show.
Concept: Ocrevus clinical trials and their outcomes for relapsing multiple sclerosis patients.
